content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												This game is so much better than the Metascore would indicate. I think a lot of the negativity is due to the numerous bugs that were in the game when launched. They seemed to have fixed/improved all the major issues. That said, it is one of the best games I have played on Steam since Portal 2. I preface this by saying that I was a huge fan of the original board game and prefer turn-based strategy to real-time.  The early missions are pretty simplistic with limited options for your crew. But get deeper into the missions--especially with the DLC missions, and you're in for a treat. The sense of claustrophobia and panic when things go wrong is very well conveyed. The addition of psychics, chain guns and the Wolf marines really adds a lot of different strategies and to the overall awesomeness of the game. The game itself has a great look generally, although the cut-scene animations where you waste the genestealers look pretty cheesy. The game is reasonably priced as are the DLC missions.  Highly recommended to fans of the board game or Warhammer 40K fanboys.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Space Hulk is based on a Table Top game based in the Warhammer universe.  This game is a pretty direct translation of those game rules.  Firing, defending, melee attacking are all based on dice roll values.  It should be noted that this game was inspired by "Aliens" with you being in control of a small group of elite soldier trying to survive in the face of a vicious overwhelming enemy.  And after playing it, that is exactly what it felt like.You are put in control of the Space Marine's elite soldiers named the Terminators, and your mission is to board a derelict space hulk (Ginormous Space Marine vessel) and complete objectives within the ship using your small team of Terminators, all the while, monstrous aliens named Tyranids are trying to wipe out your squad be swarming them (much like the zerg).This is a turnbased Strategy game where you move your guys on your turn, then the enemy moves their guys on their turn.  Your Terminators have a set amount of action points individually, and then at the beginning of the round you get a random amount of community action points that anyone can use (1-6 points).  The level begins with you placing your Terminators in their starting zone in the order that you want.  After that you decide how you are going to move them, where they will hold defensively, etc etc.  When it is the enemies turn, they will spawn units in set locations on the map, but they will randomly decide which of those locations they will spawn the enemies.  Do they feel like using all of their units on two spots? Or will they spread them out among the 6 they have at their disposal?Every decision you make will have an affect on the outcome of the mission, even squad placement at the beginning of the level.  One of the main reasons for this is because the corridors are only wide enough for one person.  Once that person is in the front, you cannot shoot through him or manouver around him.  Your guy at the front run out of ammo?  Well, unless there is a big junction in the area, he will probably end up dying since he can't fire on incoming enemies.  This really makes you think about how you move and where you place your Terminators in conjunction with how do you use their role properly (Flamethrower can hose down an entire corridor with fire for one turn, effectively cutting the enemy off from that route...or your normal assault rifle people can go on over watch to fire upon the enemy on the enemies movement turn, utilizing chokepoints to stay in control of the battlefield.)  One wrong move, one vital loss, can turn your plan inside out as the enemy surrounds your Terminators rendering chokepoints useless.The game itself is pretty well done.  I haven't run into many bugs, and none that were experience ruining/gamebreaking, just a couple of visual bugs which is pretty normal for any game.  One of the small gripes I have with the game is, in certain situations (only one situation I can think of ATM), you can't trust the movement AI to move your men the way you want, making you spend more action points than you needed to.  It's ok though, after you play for an hour or so, you realize where it gets confused and you just have to micromanage a small amount during those times.  Even if you forget or mess up, you can undo your last action.  One other small grip is the mouse control.  Left mouse click is used for everything, meaning selection AND movement.  Accidentally click a square instead of a person?  Welp, your current selection will start moving.  They could have avoided this by making left click selection and right click movement.  Not a big problem, I've only accidentally done that twice and both times I was able to hit undo, so no harm no foul.The gamelength is somewhat average. There is 2 chapters available, one being an introduction and tutorial with no length, and the more meaty chapter consisting of about 8-10 levels.  I have only completed about 5-6 levels so far and have spent about 30 minutes to an hour per level.  There are other Chapters available for download via DLC for about 5 dollars a chapter.Multiplayer is available, although I have not played it.  And unfortunately, there is no map editor for the community to use its imagination and make cool new maps, which is unfortunate because that is one of the big advantages of playing the tabletop: Making your own stories. (and lets be honest, dedicated fans have and always will make the best maps for any game...it would not be that hard to include a map editor for how simple it is to develop maps for this.  Straight corridors, doors, junctions, tiny rooms, all tile based...simplistic pieces put together to make a more complex challenge)I don't like to add some kind of random number to games, I will just say that if you like Warhammer 40k lore/universe and you like games like X-COM, chances are you will like this game.  If you like turnbased strategy games in general, you'd probably enjoy this game.  You can probably complete it on your first run through in around 6-10 hours.  I personally feel somewhat satisfied, but wishing that it had maybe at least 1 more chapter.  To me it is worth the price, but just barely.  No map creator makes it harder to recommend, but non-the-less, I still recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 30, 2013
												What a truly atrocious game. This game is retched. It's nigh unplayable....What's interesting here is that we have a game that really *shouldn't* be this bad. I mean if you look at all the different aspects of the game, they are all good. BUT when it comes to games, you NEED to have one factor above the others or it brings the whole thing down to the lowest common denominator. And that's what's happened in Space Hulk. They've got 95% of a great game here, they just ♥♥♥♥ed up the most important 5%. The control.I mean, why the f**k did they even bother? Imagine I cooked you a beautiful cake. It's got icing. It's a large portion. It looks beautiful, and to top it all off, it's low in calories. Great right? Well, what If I poured a big load of salt in it? It turns out that it's worthless right? The most important thing about food is that 1) You can eat it, and it 2) tastes good. Well, guess the duck what? Games aren't that different. If you want a good game the two most important things you need are 1) you can PLAY IT and 2) It's FUN.And that's the problem! Space Hulk just isn't playable. They poured a big, big, big, big, big, big bag of salt into the games controls. I know for a fact that the game should be fun. The game is based on a very popular board game that is *VERY* fun. So I know that the underlying mechanics of the game would be fun, they've just been implemented poorly. To go back to our food analogy, let's pretend I have baked a new cake. Not only does this one not have an♥♥♥♥♥load of salt, but the cake tastes absolutely amazing. Now, I'm going to offer you a slice of this fantastic tasting cake. Only, the thing is, I'm not going to give you a fork and I'm not going to give you a plate. Nope, you'll have to eat it off the floor, and for every bite you take, I'm going to burn you with a lit cigarette.And that's what it's like playing Space Hulk.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Space Hulk is a very good turn based representation of the Games Workshop board game.  The graphics are good and Full Control added animation speed up options for those too impatient to wait for their terminators to move.  They have been pretty good pushing out patches for fixes and recently rolled out cross platform operation with the iPad.  I personally have not had any major glitch issues with the game.  The current multiplayer role is only PvP with coop supposedly on the way.  The missions follow that same liner theme as the original board game with short intros.  Campaigns last about 6 missions.  If your idea of fun is mindlessly mashing buttons and hopping around to beat levels as fast as possible, you may want to make a different choice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Supposedly, the Imperium sends Terminators to delve deep into the twisted masses of derelicts known as Space Hulks because only they are strong enough to face the horrors within. Given the life expectancy of Terminators in this game, regular Space Marines must spontaneously combust the moment they breath space hulk air. This game is an extremely faithful recreation of the original board game. Don't go into this expecting an epic story (For the record, the story: Space Hulk filled with bad things. Here are many guns. Go kill now.), an action-packed thrill-a-minute roller coaster, or a graphical tour-de-force. Sometimes a mission will be failed because the dice hate you and your Seargeant can't hit the broad side of a genestealer and your guns jam after every shot. Sometimes you'll realize too late that the guy with the flamethrower is at the back of the troop column marching single file through the dark corridors. And sometimes you'll win.Either way, go into this game with the right expectations and you'll be well rewarded. For instance, remember that, like the board game it's based on, Space Hulk is best taken in two to three hours sessions, not marathons.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												As a teen 20 years ago I discovered 40k, and soon after discovered Space Hulk I have many fond memories of playing, weather it was in the backyard shed cutting class at school with a couple buddies or just hangin out. Space hulk was one of the games we actually played a lot instead of just painting and dreaming about playing. Back then We would talk about how cool a futuristic video game versoin would be. The versions from that era never really satisfied as they weren't really the game. They were much like the game but maybe more first person action oriented like the 3DO and Playstation versoins. or the horrible graphics Amiga before that. I played them all but now I've played that game I always wanted. that Computer remake that is simply the board game remade with online and multiplayer support, it will even have a level editor. It's just what I really wanted from a Space Hulk game, everything works and will only get better as the dev team continues to work on it. The dificulty and tatics are just like I remember them, The animations need some work but the graphics are solid and look good. The controls and hud have everthing you need easily accessible. The menu's are quick and responsive and the sound is good. I would recommend Space Hulk to anyone who loved the boardgame and also anyone who enjoys brutally hard, slower paced, strategic and tatical gameplay.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I'm a longtime fan of Space Hulk (my dad raised me on the board game), so this was a must have for me. Couldn't really recommend it beyond that, though. I grabbed it on sale at $4.99 - probably wouldn't have, otherwise, despite my fandom. If you're reading this outside of sale season, just be patient and wait for it to drop like I did. The visuals are dated and the animations are repetitive, and I would have liked to see more cinematics, but that's not a huge turn-off, considering the price. This is, simply put, an extremely faithful digital reproduction of the classic board game. The AI is on point, but the difficulty ramp is fraking steep and the random number generator produces 1s at what seems to be a statistically anomolous rate. If I had d6s roll the way they do in this game I'd have thrown them away by now. Anyway, fun way to get my fix when I can't con my friends into playing the board game, and if you're a Space Hulk or tabletop 40k fan, go ahead and pick it up. If you're looking for something faster-paced in the 40k universe I'd recommend Dawn of War 1 and 2 (if you're looking for RTS) or Space Marine if you're more the shooty type.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This game is a very close recreation of the Space Hulk board game.  If you enjoy the board game (or could not find a copy of the 3rd edition version) this is an excellent purchase that I fully recommend.If you have not played Space Hulk, but like Warhammer 40K, I also recommend this game for the atmosphere.  So far the game seems to capture the feel of 40K pretty well.  It is kind of like the Dawn of War series in that regard, but focused solely on Terminators and Genestealers.  Hopefully they will expand the game in the future using other units and/or races from 40K (which were given some rules in old White Dwarf articles.)If you don't know about warhammer 40K or Space Hulk, this is still a very good squad based game.  It is turn based, which until recently had been hard to find.  While I believe something like XCOM is a better turn based squad game, this one is also quite good, but limited compared to that game.  There in not advancement, force management, or other features.  This is pure turn based mission execution.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone interested in a turn based squad game.  However, Warhammer 40K fans and those that know and love the Space Hulk board game will be the most impressed with it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Space Hulk is a simple, challenging tactical boardgame.  Once you learn to use overwatch, it's not hard to beat, but additional challenges for achievements and keeping all your men alive through a mission make the game much more difficult.  There's not a great deal of story or lore involved; it doesn't tell you much about the 40k world, but if you're looking for a simple challenge in turn-based tactics, this is a good game to sink time into.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												A largely-faithful recreation of the boardgame, and as such it plays like a boardgame. Your squad(s) and their loadouts are preselected based on the mission, and gameplay is centered around managing Action Points and a variable pool of Command Points, with additional resource management required when dealing with assault cannons and heavy flamers (both of which have limited ammunition). If the odds are in your favor you can park Sargeant Gideon and his impressively large hammer in a chokepoint and watch as he stomps 14 Genestealers in a single game. If the odds are not in your favor you'll watch him go down to the first melee attack launched against him.If you are looking for a fully featured 40K experience this is not it and it is not meant to be. On the other hand if you're a fan of the Space Hulk boardgame, or of boardgames in general, then this game is certainly worth giving a whirl.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												They could've done so much more with this IP. Decades worth of material for reference, and modern squad-based games to take note from (XCOM) but this game ultimately falls short. The characters move far too slow, the missions are too similiar, there is nowhere near enough choice of weaponry or armour (I would've liked to see Dawn of War 2-style ultimate Warhammer hero customisation) and the difficulty balance is all over the place. The developers obviously tried to stay as close as possible to the original board game, and that is very admirable of them. But it didn't transfer well to computers. A giant shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Ok, so I'll start out by saying that I am a fan of the whole Warhammer 40k universe. I can't say that I am a veteran, as most of my experience is limited to reading 40k wiki articles and playing the Dawn of War games, but I have found this game quite enjoyable. That being said, the game is still best bought on sale. The game only comes with 15 missions and some will take an hour or more to beat. Multiplayer is limited (some maps are heavily unbalanced because your are playing the missions for single player). They seem to keep pumping out content, which is good and I certianly don't regret buying during the winter sale.There are some issues (some of the missions are impossible if the genestealers swarm hard from certain approaches at the start of the game), but for the most part each mission is interesting and fun. Yes, sometimes you have to sacrifice marines to achieve the mission, but I guess the same is true for the board game and real combat.Basic rundown of the mechanics of the game: (1) Space marines die in close quarters, hallways are your friend in conjunction with overwatch. Keep as much of a hallway between you and the first point your marine can see the beastie and he will cut them down...usually (jams and the mission where you don't have sustained fire can cause even the best positioned marine to die) (2) The game has (for most missions) an endless supply of genestealers, so you must achieve the objective while being constantly harassed by genestealer that seem to favor spawning where the biggest clump of your marines(though this is not a law, sometimes a lone marine will be swarmed). (3) Actions and movements are based on AP that your marines get at the begining of battle (4 for each marine, genestealers get 6) and are used for everything from moving, shooting, opening doors, and entering blessed overwatch. You also get a randomly generated number of CP that can be used for anything AP are use for and probably most critically, unjaming weapons during the genestealer's turn (where they are hopefully being mowed down by overwatch.If you give the game a chance and you like 40k it will be worth your time playing.Cleanse the xenos. Burn the witch. Purge the heretic.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2013
												I have the first version, unpatched. So bear in mind it might become better. I like the assault cannon, but that's about it. Now, I love the Warhammer 40K franchise, but this is my least favorite of them all. Even worse than the stale mate Dark Crusade and Soulstorm. There is something infuriatingly SLOW about the whole thing and you wait a lot to see enemies move, and even the initial deployment of the squad is unnecessarily slow and has this ugly delay where the app-like alert lingers way too long. Geez, can I just get to the action already!? There's not even an option to set a faster speed. Worst of all you can play for a really long time and then lose horribly in just a few turns, so you're just not up for endless SLOWMO again and again and again. Also, even for a simple game like this, the interface is annoying. It's a precision game, and it's such a disaster to accidentally move a character, but it easily happens, especially since there appears to be no easy (mouse) way to get out of the "move mode". Would it really have hurt to let the right mouse button work like an escape. If, like me, you own all of the Warhamme 40K games, you'll think this is a "must have". Sadly, it's not.  In my cycle these developers would be in trouble.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												I don't know what kind of horrid bugs this game had when it came out, but I don't think they are there anymore. You can safely ignore the metacritic score, if you ever paid attention to it, for this reason. The game is fully functional at this point.This game is very similar to the XCOM games, except that the game is set in the War40k universe. You command a small squad or squads to wander the decaying halls of a space hulk. Your enemy is the Tyranid race, specifically Genestealers. The area is really cramped, and you are forced to send your squad through the halls one at a time, covering the flanks and rear. The mood is very tense, and you can be sure that you are not at all safe. You will probably die a lot until you figure out how to optimally position your squad. The UI is really simple and clean, so that will not be an issue. You gun will jam frequently due to the fact that enemies have a tendency to start pouring out of nowhere en masse whenever they feel like it. This will leave you vulnerable, unless you learn to prepare. Any enemy coming within melee range has about a 60% chance of killing you.  Basically, this is a Space Hulk game. If you know what that is, you know everything there is to know about this game. It's a digital recreation of the game with voice acting, which is alright. The game's standard price is a little bit high.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This game is a very close recreation of the Space Hulk board game.  If you enjoy the board game (or could not find a copy of the 3rd edition version) this is an excellent purchase that I fully recommend.If you have not played Space Hulk, but like Warhammer 40K, I also recommend this game for the atmosphere.  So far the game seems to capture the feel of 40K pretty well.  It is kind of like the Dawn of War series in that regard, but focused solely on Terminators and Genestealers.  Hopefully they will expand the game in the future using other units and/or races from 40K (which were given some rules in old White Dwarf articles.)If you don't know about warhammer 40K or Space Hulk, this is still a very good squad based game.  It is turn based, which until recently had been hard to find.  While I believe something like XCOM is a better turn based squad game, this one is also quite good, but limited compared to that game.  There in not advancement, force management, or other features.  This is pure turn based mission execution.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone interested in a turn based squad game.  However, Warhammer 40K fans and those that know and love the Space Hulk board game will be the most impressed with it.

												The negative reviews across the net appear to be out of date.  This rendition of Space Hulk is surprisingly challenging, but quite smooth in gameplay.  Although the squads are not evenly balanced, (melee god sgt and auto cannon vs balanced sgt and flamer) it doesn't distract from the fun. 												Like Space Hulk?  Then get this game.  It's Space Hulk.  A new minor changes aside, it's the exact board game you know and love, made into a faithful computer game equivalent.  The main complaints I've seen regarding the game are some of the items from the board game that don't translate as well to computer form.  Despite added animations, it's a fairly staic game, although the lighting and sounds add some atmosphere.  The movement is clunky (what do you expect they're Terminators!) and they prbably ould have put an option in to speed up the animation.  They only (admittedly minor) grip I have regarding the way they did the rules is that it wll automatically spend your action points on unjamming your guns, even if you'd rather spend them another way.  This may get patched out at some point, but I haven't seen that yet.  So finally, if you enjoy Space Hulk, or even just 40k, get the game.  It's worth it.

												Decent conversion of an awesome board game into a PC game, but a bit pricey for what you get. The graphics and animations are sub-par for the PC platform and the game really needs the co-op mode we've been promised (in progress, we hope) and more campaigns/maps (hoping the community steps in here). content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Let me just start out by saying that this game definitely isn't for everyone. It's for people who like the board game, or want to try it out and don't want to drop $250 on a physical copy off eBay.  If you have no idea how Space hulk works, you probably shouldn't even bother. You'll just be frustrated by the randomness of the whole thing.That said, I really enjoy it. I didn't at first, however. If you have no idea of what you do in Space Hulk, the game will feel impossible as a single Genestealer completely rips apart half your squad in one turn. Space Hulk is a dice game, where luck is a major factor. Where in the actual game, missing 5 shots in a row as your friend slowly advances a Genestealer would be just hilarious, in the video game it just becoems frustrating. Or if your weapon jams 4 times in a row.Animations are slow for the Terminators. So you're probably best disabling the timer, as slow animaation aren't something you have to deal with in the actual game. you can speed them up, but they just look silly. The first-person shoulder cam is cinematic, but isn't used often enough, and needs an option to be bigger. Graphics-wise, it's nothing too impressive. The astetics are perfect, you really feel like you're trundling through the tight corridors of a space hulk. Sounds are good, but possibly repetative over time. I'm mostly listening to something else when I play, so I don't notice.There are a few differenced from the board game. They don't really hurt the game, in my opinion though. They just help ease some of the frustrations.TL;DR, If you like the board game, or like the Warhammer 40k universe, and don't mind the random element, you will probably enjoy this.  Otherwise, you may want to stay away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is a faithful recreation of the board game, more specifically the newer re-release (which I may or may not have on my shelf), to a fault.  The underlying mechanics use simulated D6 rolls and the mission maps for the main campaign are even ripped straight from the manual.  Hard to say if it was GW or the devs, but there was some missed room for improvement and refinement of the formula.There are no hybrids or patriarchs as in the original, instead we have the broodlords form the newer version.  It reduces the variety for anyone wanting to play genesteelers, but I suppose it makes it easier to balance.  Ultimately, there isn't too much room for strategy on the geensteeler side, which is why it's fitting the campaign plays from the Terminator's perspective.If you enjoy the boardgame or have nostalgia for the original, there's something here to enjoy.  But if you don't know what Space Hulk or Warhammer 40K are, I'm not sure I can really recomend this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Great nostalgia trip/time sink for 40k afficionados and tabletop fans.  Lack of variety of enemies is a little disappointing, but the missions are varied enough that the game remains challenging and interesting, with some very intense scrapes if you push for some of the achievements.Its a little disappointing that you only get to use terminators, as they start to feel very plain, especially against the very scary genestealers - you almost forget what killing machines they actually are in the broader 40k conext.  I'd love for Full Control to get a chance to remake space crusade, so that we could use a wider variety of units - scouts and space marines as well as terminators against the likes of the orks, eldar and chaos as well.I hope there is a long tail of content for this game, more campaigns and hopefully a map editor and painter tools for custom campaigns.  Space Hulk is a strong base to start from, and I'm sure there are plenty of diehard fans out there willing to fork out for more adventures with the emperor's finest.7/10, solid.

												You have to understand that this is meant to be a replica of a physical  boardgame. If however you are a fan of the original and don't mind the steep price for what it is then you may very well enjoy it.My largest complaints are the steep price tag and the DLC which seems a little too costly as well. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												It's...the board game. Not much more and not much less. Not to say this is necessarily a bad thing, it's a fun game for people who enjoy turn based board games with lots of dice rolling and strategy. However this isn't a video game adaptation of the board game, it's literally a "port" of the game straight onto the PC. This isn't a 40k XCOM. It feels a bit unpolished, and there are definitely some annoyances to work around. But if you played and enjoyed the board game, or enjoy other games of this nature, it's worth buying (not for full price though, I'd recommend at least a 50% sale). There are a few annoyances but it's a very faithful port of the original board game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												"Space Hulk" is computer version of the tactical board game - nothing more, nothing less. It is based on 3rd Edition of rules (down to the names and equipment of the marines) and includes all the missions from the original mission book and well as three bonus assigments plus three tutorial ones. You can buy additional campaigns, but I haven't tried them yet. As funny as it sounds, this is the first turn-based adaptation, as both 1993 'Space Hulk' and 1995 'Space Hulk: Vengeance of Blood Angels' were played in real-time with limited active pause.The game itself in of a 'simple to learn, hard to master' variety. Forces and are pre-determined for every mission and there is no real possibility of customising them in any way. Array of actions is also very limited - it is a game of strategic positioning and area coverage with a liberal amount of random element (combat is resolved by simulated dice roll). So, moving, turning and shooting in cramped spaces with 4-5 action points per unit, where most actions use up one AP). You get the idea. The game may seem slow and limited but even a slightest error migh lead to demise. Especially when you turn the turn time limit.  You might feel claustrophobic at first but this is the idea of game - not choosing from many tactical opportunities, but using the their limited array to a maximum. All thing considered, not unlike chess. A nice change from numerous  hectic tactical games.The game includes a multiplayer mode with a hot-seat option is a nice addition. Now you can play a Space Hulk game with a live opponent without buying the board game (tkat is more expensive) or even getting together to play a mission or two. Addition of co-op mode is a nice touch too (it reminds me a bit of 'Death Angel' card game by FFG).I feel obliged to warn people not interested in Warhammer 40000 universe though, because for causal gamers this game might prove too challenging and monotonous, while seasoned armchair generals might yearn for more complexity. You might also be put off by the very limited surroundings - all missions use virtually the same few map elements, only the floorplans change. But if you missed good old times of 'Laser Squad' you might give 'Space Hulk' a try.Graphics and sound are nothing to write home about but do not offend either. The game is a good piece of craftsmanship, the models and surroundings definitely keep the Warhammer 40000 atmosphere. camera window adds to it but after a while starts to annoy (you can turn it off though). Music and battle sounds are of similar kind.Is it worth it? Well, as an alternative to boardgame - definitely yes, as even at full price it is way cheaper than the fully tangible version. As a standalone game - it depends. You get 15 missions, and 4 additional campaigns with 5 mission each (5 EUR / 3 GBP / 7 USD) a piece. So, full collection might be a bit pricey, so I recommend waiting for a discount.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Not disappointed with the game, but duly disappointed with the marketing. The game functions as a great and attractive facimilite of both the original board game, and it's previous PC iterations. The action is fun and the atmosphere is right. The game requires strategy and will challenge you. The bad? You get 2 campaigns for the asking price, and the rest of them are being sold in a micro-transaction store. 80% of the game available at release is being held back to gouge you. Buy it if they offer it as a complete pack, but the way they marketed this one is just insulting. That's all I've got to say about that.

Posted: July 21, 2015
												Excellent port of the board game no one will play with me anymore!  Just bear in mind: it doesn't stand up to more modern types of survival games, being that it is a direct translation of a board game made in 1989.  Video gamers might want to stick to XCOM and it's ilk.  If you're looking for an authentic Games Workshop board game experience without the setup or need for hardcore tabletop gamers like yourself, then get this.Though a fantastic port, it could've used a bit more spit and polish.  Be patient/use Google as you figure out the best way to get your terminators to do precisely what you want. And, whatever you do, don't forget to max the play speed in the settings menu!  Sheesh!

												Just bought the game for $7.49 at the current Humble Bundle sale and for that price, this game is alright (but not worth $30 imo).It plays very much like the board game, so if your expectations are in line with that... then maybe you'll be OK.  Graphics are functional at best.  AI could be better... it is often not aggressive enough, attacks aren't co-ordinated, and it doesn't use the most optimal spawn points.I enjoyed the game for one playthrough and played a couple of games online (which works well, but lacks players).  Played the Space Hulk board game long, long ago, so part of my recommendation is based on nostalgia.  I think the Metacritic score was a bit harsh.

												Turn based board game reproduced into a computer game. There is not much more what to tell here. But here is something you will encounter if you will buy and play it.+ Warhammer 40K setting. Coridors, a bit of dungeon crawler feeling without rpg. Good atmosphere if you will put yourself in and try your best. Space marines have shoulder cams so you can see the action from their poit of view.+ High difficulty if you want to follow board game rules (but you can make it even harder for yourself with time limits), expect loses and count with moves where you will wilingly sacrifice your soldiers to complete the mission.+ Good production values, graphic, sounds and naration is well done.+- Randomnes in everything. Its the same with board game where you throw dices for all actions.- Focused mainly at WH40K fans.- Lack of story.

Posted: August 18, 2013
												This is a strict and faithful adaptation of the famous Space Hulk board game. This game has very little in terms of bells and whistles - character animations are clunky, basic, and repetitive, music is almost non-existent, and sound effects are cookie-cutter. Overall, I'd say it is a good effort and that Full Control achieved their goal of adapting the board game, but I feel that they priced it outside of its percieved level of quality. I really can't recommend this above the $15 price point.

Posted: August 17, 2013
												If you love Warhammer 40k you may like this, or (obviously) if you like the Space Hulk board game.  I got caught up in the hype of a good review and I decided to buy this.  It is *NOT* what I expected at all and really, really not worth 30 bucks.  I should have done some research before I grabbed this one.  Lesson learned - one good review does NOT a good game make.  It is one of the most basic, and boring, strategy games I have ever played.  Sure, the armor is cool - but if you get hit one time... you die.  Your big, tough terminators may as well be wearing a speedo (A space speedo, ok?  You know what I mean... sheesh.).  Save your dough and go buy something good like Orcs must Die! 2 or Eador: Masters of the Broken World or, hell, Plants versus Zombies.  (Speaking of zombies - check out Dead State and State of Decay!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Love it.I simply love this game. To sum up my surprise with how good it is, I generally hate turn based games. However, I love the look and feel of Warhammer 40K so I decided to finally splurge on some of the games, and I don't regret it. This is my favourite so far. If I ever find this board game, I am 100% buying it, because it is just pure fun and enjoyment. The lurking around, the strategy, the being cornered by a line of Genestealers and mowing them down with a flamethrower, its all there and it's fantastic. I bought 4 copies of this game for my friends and I and do not regret it. It can be intense, hilarious, and downright unfair, but it's fun the whole ride. This game has a lot of great aspects to it, especially the visuals. The way your Terminator walks around, the environment, the lighting, all of it is great. The color scheme as well adds to th overall experience of th egame, with some nice contrasting colors that pop out. The sounds in the game are great as well, with very nice voices for the terminators and weapons, just the sound in general is good.Level design is great as well if you ask me. Every room/area has its own advantages and purpose, and this can b egreatly utilized to the player's advantage. It makes the strategy a bit easier to grasp and gives you the chance for redemption in every new area.The only downsides to the game are a few bugs, the not-so-uncommon bad roll of the dice (which for me personally is a pro as it is hilarious) and some odd choices for the animations. The only consistent bug I have found in the game is that occasionally a unit will be selected, then stay selected even when you finish using all their points. this is more common in Genestealers, as I will "END UNIT" and it will continue to stay selected and I will be unable to choose another unit. This has been solved when I select the unit as though I am intending to turn him to another direction, then wildly spinning and a new unit is selected. I can only describe this as annoying as it generally appens to only one unit, but it has happened in 2/5 games I have played online, so it could become a very infuriating bug in the future. The animations are only considered odd to me for the Genestealers. Some of their movement is odd, mainly bevause they always act as though nothing is around them until attacking. This is a minor complaint as the quality of the animations are good, it's just odd looking at a horde of Genestealers staring down a Terminator and acting as though they are doing nothing, licking the air endlessly and generally being in their own little world.Lastly is the dice rolls. Being a board game running off of a dice rolling system, you're gonna have some bad streaks. This however, has never infuriated me in any game I've played so far, as I and my friends find it hilarious. A large, probably 1-2 ton Terminator the size of the hallways he occupies is standing directly in front of a Genestealer. The Terminator attacks with his chaingun. He shoots dozens, even hundreds of bullets and misses, and it is hilarious. The idea of someone being that dense, so unable to fight yet being in the situation, is just the funniest thing to me. This is even funnier when considering you only have to be hit once to die, so say that rule is true, he only has to hit the Genestealer once, but no, he misses all of them. Oh, but he can cross-map snipe with the chaingun and never miss a shot. It's just when his life depends on it he can't fight. This may be a very infuriating thing to some players, which is why it could be seen as a con, but I find it hilarious and adding to the fun of the game. Overall, I'd say this is a strong yes. It has gotten me into a genre that I previously thought I couldn't enjoy, given me and my friends something to laugh about, and offers a fun singleplayer campaign with cool levels. It's a great game, and I'd highly recommend it.Just be warned, some of these games can last over an hour, possibly even two, but it's still TONS of fun!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												A true PC version of the TTG, complete with dice rolls.+Lots of maps, even more if you get the DLC.  Your troops are somewhat disposable (they will be back for the next mission) making those heroic charges / sacrifices more tolerable.-No character progression.  I would like more difficulty levels (some levels are easy when set to "hard" difficulty).  The AI isn't terribly clever.  You can't change your squad composition or terminator loadout.I think it's fun.  It runs well, no bugs or crashes.  It is slow TBS goodness like the TTG.
